channel.title: Talks on Nathan Oseroff
channel.description: Recent content in Talks on Nathan Oseroff

item.title: Why Almost Everyone Misunderstands The Problem(s) of Demarcation
The Return of a Demarcation Problem
item.description:
A previous version of this talk was presented at the Triennial International Conference of the Italian Society for Logic and the Philosophy of Science at University of Bologna on Aug 23, 2017. The website is available here.

Another version of this talk was presented at the Nordic Network for Philosophy of Science at University of Copenhagen on April 19, 2017. The website is available here.

A later version of this talk was presented at the Advanced Research Seminar at King’s College London.

item.title: Conceptual Spaces as a Framework for Pedagogy in the Sciences
Two Diachronic Grounds for Movement Within Conceptual Spaces
Meeting the Scientific Anti-Realist's Epistemic Burdens
item.description: A revised version of this talk was given at the Advanced Research Seminar at King’s College London on Oct 21, 2015.

item.title: The Overpopulation of Solutions to Philosophical Problems
item.description: A revised version of this talk was given at the First Year Research Seminar at King’s College London on May 13, 2015.

item.title: Why Deflationist Theories of Knowledge Deserve Consideration
Problems the History of Science Presents for Accepting Counter-Closure
item.description:
An early version of this talk was presented at the Eastern Pennsylvania Philosophical Association Conference at Misericordia University. Feb 8, 2014. An article about the event is available here.

Another version of this talk was presented at the Thirteenth Annual Student Philosophy Symposium at Georgia State University on Feb 2, 2014. A copy of the program is available here.

At the conference I received the Robert A. Almeder Award for best graduate paper in philosophy.

The earliest version of this talk was entitled ‘Counter-Closure, Factivity and Inferential Knowledge’, and was presented at the First Year Research Seminar at King’s College London, on Sep 24, 2014.

item.title: Why is it that, if Counter-Closure is Accepted, There is a Problem for Inferential Knowledge?
Scientific Institutions, Norms, and the Limits of Learning from Experience
item.description: A variation of this talk was presented at South Carolina Society for Philosophy Conference at Furman University on Feb 14, 2014.

item.title: The Tu Quoque and the Theistic Stance
item.description: A later version of this talk was presented at the Hammond Society at Johns Hopkins University on Jan 20, 2014.

item.title: Virtue Negativism and the Norms of Scientific Institutions
item.description: Variation of talk presented at South Carolina Society for Philosophy Conference at Furman University on Feb 14, 2014.

item.title: Sellars and the Myth of the Given
